Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Trade-driven relocation of ground-level SO<sub>2</sub> concentrations across Chinese provinces based on satellite observations.

AbstractText: The influence of trade on ground-level SO<sub>2</sub> concentrations in China was evaluated based on multiregional input-output (MRIO) analysis, using the ozone monitoring instrument (OMI) SO<sub>2</sub> columns and SO<sub>2</sub> profiles from an atmospheric chemical and transport model, MOZART-4. The provincial sum of ground-level SO<sub>2</sub> concentrations has a good consistency with the provincial SO<sub>2</sub> emissions (R = 0.65, p < 0.01). The provincial SO<sub>2</sub> concentrations presented strong spatial variations, with a range of 5.1-50.6 μg/m<sup>3</sup> and an average of 19.7 μg/m<sup>3</sup> across China. The international trade increased the SO<sub>2</sub> concentrations in all of the provinces and increased the national population-weighted SO<sub>2</sub> (PWM-SO<sub>2</sub>) concentration by 2.9 μg/m<sup>3</sup>. Interprovincial trade within China decreased the ambient SO<sub>2</sub> concentrations in Beijing, Tianjin, and Chongqing and the provinces in southeast and central China, but increased SO<sub>2</sub> in the remaining provinces of China. In general, interprovincial trade decreased the national PWM-SO<sub>2</sub> concentration by 5.3 μg/m<sup>3</sup>.
